conversation.message: Hello School_B admissions team—I'm Student_A. School_B is my first choice and I’m very interested in joining. Could you share what qualities or achievements you prioritize most when deciding among applicants this year? I’d like to understand how to present my fit clearly.

To keep School_B as an option while not burning the round, I will start with a TALK to signal strong interest and ask what they value, so I can tailor a stronger APPLY in a later round if there is any chance.

conversation.message:
Hi Student_A—thanks for reaching out and for your interest in School_B.

In general, we look for (1) strong and consistent academic performance, (2) evidence of initiative and sustained commitment (clubs, projects, leadership, service), and (3) clear fit with our community—how you’ll contribute and what you hope to pursue here. Specific, concrete examples help more than broad statements.

If you’d like, reply with 2–3 of your most meaningful activities/achievements and what you learned from them, plus what programs or areas you’re most excited to engage with at School_B. That will help us understand your fit better.
conversation.thought: As School_B, my true priority ranks Student_A last. In this round, I have [APPLY] messages from Student_B (ranked #2) and Student_C (ranked #3), both indicating willingness to commit. With quota 1, I should avoid encouraging or committing to Student_A now, keep the conversation non-committal, and preserve flexibility to match with a higher-priority applicant. Student_A only sent [TALK], so no accept/reject decision is required; respond with [TALK] and request concrete info while not signaling likely admission.

Since we must respond to Student_C’s [APPLY] with accept/reject, the best strategy to maximize match quality is to reject C to keep the seat available for higher-priority applicants (especially B, potentially E).

I’m especially excited to get involved in academic clubs and collaborative projects, and I’m looking for a place where I can take on responsibility and grow.

If admitted, School_A would be one of my top choices among the remaining options, and I would take the offer very seriously. Thank you for your consideration.

conversation.message:
Hello Student_E—thank you for checking in and for your continued interest. At the moment, we are still holding our remaining seat for applicants who are higher on our priority order. Because of that, an immediate-commitment confirmation or additional materials would not change our decision right now.

That said, if our higher-priority candidates do not apply to us (or become matched elsewhere) and we still have an open seat in a later round, we may be able to reconsider at that time. If you would like, you can message us again in a later round to confirm you are still available and willing to accept immediately, and we will reassess based on the market situation then.
conversation.thought: As School_E, my true priority list is A > C > B > E > D, and I have quota 1 still open. Student_E is on my list but is ranked below A/C/B. Since I can leave the seat unfilled rather than take someone outside my list, the key question is whether waiting could plausibly yield Student_A/Student_C/Student_B. Those students all rank School_E low (A and D have E as 4th; B has E as 5th; C has E as 4th), so they may only come to me late if rejected elsewhere. However, accepting Student_E now would block the chance to take A/C/B if they later apply. Student_E has already applied twice and I rejected, indicating I am holding for higher-priority candidates. In this round Student_E is only asking via [TALK]; I should be transparent that I would only reconsider if higher-priority candidates are no longer available/likely, but I cannot commit now. Therefore respond with [TALK] and clarify conditions/timeline without promising admission.
